Changing Java version procedure under linux

Source: vignettes/Changing_java_version_linux.Rmd
Changing_java_version_linux.Rmd

Java 8 installation

Switching on the system the java version launched using java command to Java 8.

To do so the following script can be run

#!/bin/bash

# Changing current version to 8
echo "The current Java version is : "
java -version

version=$(java -version 2>&1 | awk -F '"' '/version/ {print $2}')

if ! [ -z $(echo $version | grep ^1.8) ];then
  echo "The Java version is already Java 8"
  exit 0
fi

echo "Changing Java version to Java 8"
if [ -e /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/bin/java ];then
         sudo rm /usr/bin/java
         sudo ln -s /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/bin/java /usr/bin/java
fi

if [ -z $(echo $version | grep ^1.8) ];then
  echo "Java 8 is not installed !"
  exit 1
fi

echo "The Java version is now : "
java -version
## The current Java version is : 
## openjdk version "1.8.0_222"
## OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_222-8u222-b10-1~14.04-b10)
## OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.222-b10, mixed mode)
## The Java version is already Java 8

Use the SticsOnR package functions using JavaStics command line interface (for the moment only run_javastics)

Switch back to the last Java version on the system.

To do so the following script can be run

#!/bin/bash

# Changing to the last version

echo "Current Java version is : "
java -version

version=$(java -version 2>&1 | awk -F '"' '/version/ {print $2}')

if [ -z $(echo $version | grep ^1.8) ];then
  echo "The Java version is not Java 8"
  exit 0
fi

sudo rm /usr/bin/java
sudo ln -s /etc/alternatives/java /usr/bin/java

echo "JAVA version is now : "
java -version
## Current Java version is : 
## openjdk version "1.8.0_222"
## OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_222-8u222-b10-1~14.04-b10)
## OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.222-b10, mixed mode)
